text.content:
The Typescene ‘App’ module defines the necessary constructs to create full featured Web applications.

At the heart of this module is the Application class. This is a singleton class, meaning there can only ever be one instance of this class each time the module is loaded.

The primary purpose of the Application class is to keep track of a ‘stack’ (a last-in-first-out list) of Activity instances. These can be synchronized with the browser’s navigation history, which makes the App module dependent on the browser window interface.

To learn how to use Application and Activity classes, refer to the Architecture topic.

text.title: What is Typescene?
text.content: This module is part of the Typescene toolkit, a strongly typed front-end toolkit for modern Web applications built with TypeScript. Read more about Typescene on the project’s website.

When deciding on the architecture of your application there are a number of things to consider, such as the way data is communicated to and from the Web server, the way it is stored in the user’s browser, and how it is presented on screen by your UI code.

Typescene can help to structure your front end user interface code in a way that is clear and concise, by adhering to a well-defined object oriented pattern. Following this pattern, the entire UI is made up of Component objects, which communicate asynchronously through (observable) properties and Signals. Components are combined in logical ways and presented on a page.

However Components do not define how a user should move from page to page or among modal dialogs, or how the application should store its internal state. This is what the App module and its Activity classes can be used for.

text.title: Dependency inversion
text.content:
Often, the first step to defining the overall application architecture is to decide on dependencies. Minimizing dependencies in code, especially mutual dependencies, is important for producing code that is easy to understand an maintain.

The Typescene App module is built to support ‘inverted’ dependencies, i.e. even though the application itself creates activities to manage application state, and activities in turn create and display UI views, the direction of dependencies in code is exactly the other way around.

  • Views know about the public API of the activity they are subscribed to, but activities do not depend on specific views;
  • Activities know about parent activities, but not the other way around; and
  • Activities subscribe to application (URL) routes to eliminate the need for a global routing map that would have to refer to classes across the app’s code base.

Using dependency inversion to your advantage, you may even wish to structure your source code such that adding a new feature (activity) to your application would only involve creating a single folder in your code base:

  • ./feature-name — folder that contains all files for a feature with this name
    • ./feature-name/FeatureActivity.ts — activity source, i.e. an implementation of a ViewActivity class (and/or other activities), mapped to an application route using mapToPath or mapToResource
    • ./feature-name/FeatureView.ts — main view source, i.e. an implementation of a UI component or page class, mapped to the activity using mapToActivity or mapPageToActivity
    • ./feature-name/components/... — optional, more view classes (sub components) that are used by the main activity view
    • ./feature-name/sub-feature/... — optional, sub activities that depend on the feature activity as a parent activity

The only issue with this structure is that tools such as Webpack will not automatically include all files in the build process. This can be solved by recursively including index.ts files for all folders, that import all source files in that folder.

text.title: About the Examples
text.content:
All examples are included here as if they are taken from the body of a sample application, which would import the Typescene toolkit as follows:

import { Async, UI, App } from "@typescene/typescene";

As a result, all exported members are prefixed with Async., UI., or App. in the examples.

Performing a simple GET request with fetch:

// outputs the content of index.html
App.Http.fetch("/index.html")
    .then(response => {
        if (!response.ok)
            throw new Error("HTTP " + response.status);
        else
            return response.text();
    })
    .then(text => {
        console.log(text);
    });

For the example above, getTextAsync works too:

// outputs the content of index.html
App.Http.getTextAsync("/index.html")
    .then(text => {
        console.log(text);
    });

And if you want to parse HTML, use getHtmlContentAsync:

// appends the content of index.html to the current document
App.Http.getHtmlContentAsync("/index.html")
    .then(fragment => {
        document.body.appendChild(fragment);
    });

Sending a POST request using postAsync with a JSON payload, and parsing the JSON response:

// sends and receives some JSON data
App.Http.postAsync("/api/items", { name: "Bob", foo: "bar" })
    .then(responseData => {
        // output the parsed response
        console.log(responseData);
    });

All of the library functions work well with the async/await pattern, too:

// sends and receives some JSON data
async function postItemAsync(data) {
    var responseData = await App.Http.postAsync("/api/items", data);

    // ... do something with responseData
    console.log(responseData);
}

postItemAsync({ name: "Bob", foo: "bar" });

Finally, you can intercept requests and return mock responses, as well as intercept genuine responses, by connecting to the provided signals: Requesting and Responded.

// intercept all requests before they are sent
App.Http.Requesting.connect(req => {
    // log all requests
    console.log("Requesting: " + req.url);

    // throw an exception if URL is not absolute
    if (!req.url || req.url.charAt(0) !== "/")
        throw new Error("Oops.");

    // send mock response for POST /api/items
    if (req.method === "POST" && req.url === "/api/items") {
        return App.Http.MockResponse.withJSONContent({ foo: "bar" });
    }
});

// redirect /api/items/{x} to /api/test/items/{x}
App.Http.Requesting.connect(req => {
    if (req.url) {
        req.url.replace(/^\/api\/items\/([^\/]+)/,
            "/api/test/items/$1");
    }
});

// take content for "/index.html" from a JSON response
App.Http.Requesting.connect(req => {
    if (req.url === "/index.html") {
        return App.Http.getAsync("/api/test/index").then(data => {
            // take text from a property and fake a response
            return new App.Http.MockResponse(
                { responseText: data.html },
                new App.Http.MockResponseHeaders(
                    "Content-Type: text/html"));
        });
    }
});

// log all (real) response statuses
App.Http.Responded.connect(res => {
    console.log("Response: " + res.status);
    // (`res` is either a real response from `window.fetch`,
    // or a MockResponse created from XMLHttpRequest data)
});

items.name: Activity
items.doc: Represents a UI activity.

items.name: ActivityOptions
items.doc: Options for an activity that determine its behavior in the activity stack.

items.name: isBackgroundActivity
items.doc: Set to true to mark this activity as a background activity; i.e. it should not be started directly, and it should be skipped when navigating back in history (enforced by Application, not ActivityStack itself, to allow background activities in the foreground temporarily, and to enable skipping past a first background activity on the stack by exiting the application).

items.name: isHubActivity
items.doc: Set to true to require this activity to be in the foreground, or move up to it, when used as a parent activity; i.e. when starting or resuming a child activity, all activities on top of the hub activity are suspended and replaced with the child activity; can be used to prevent buildup of activities on the history stack and therefore memory leaks.

items.name: isRootActivity
items.doc: Set to true to allow only one copy of an activity on the stack; i.e. when pushing an instance that is already on the stack, the stack is transitioned up to the existing instance instead; use with a singleton activity to implement e.g. an application home activity.

items.name: parentActivity
items.doc: The parent activity, if any; the activity stack will ensure the given activity (or an instance of given class) exists in its history stack when activating this activity, or insert it before.

text.title: Usage
text.content:
Set the .options property in the constructor of your activity class, to have these options enforced by the activity stack when activated.

class MyActivity extends UI.Activity {
    constructor(/* ... */) {
        super();
        this.options.parentActivity = MyParentActivity;
        // ...
    }
}

text.title: See Also
text.content: To implement a home view activity, derive from RootViewActivity.

items.name: getInstance
items.doc: Get an instance of this activity class, can be overridden to alter behavior when e.g. pushing a parent activity by class; by default simply constructs the instance without parameters.

items.name: new Activity
items.doc: Create an activity with given display title.

items.name: options
items.doc: Object that contains options for this activity (observable, not null or undefined).

items.name: title
items.doc: Display title of this activity (observable).

items.name: Activated
items.doc: Signal that is emitted after this activity is pushed to foreground.

items.name: Activating
items.doc: Signal that is emitted before this activity is pushed to foreground, if any handler throws an error then the activity is not activated.

items.name: Deactivated
items.doc: Signal that is emitted after this activity is removed from history.

items.name: Resumed
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when this activity is back in foreground.

items.name: Resuming
items.doc: Signal that is emitted before this activity is put back in foreground, if any handler throws an error then the activity is not suspended.

items.name: Suspended
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when this activity is no longer in foreground.

items.name: Suspending
items.doc: Signal that is emitted before another activity is pushed to foreground, if any handler throws an error then the activity is not suspended.

text.title: See Also
text.content:
Activities live on an activity stack implemented by ActivityStack.

The most frequently used activity stack is part of the Application instance, which can be used to start and stop activities.

items.name: ActivityResourceMap
items.doc: Represents a mapping of paths to activity providers (routes).

items.name: obtainAsync
items.doc: Get a promise that resolves to a list of activities that are registered for given path (#/… or /… or full href, %-decoded).

items.name: register
items.code: register(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[], callback: (...params: string[]) => Activity | Activity[] | PromiseLike<Activity | Activity[]> | undefined): Async.SignalConnection;
items.doc: Add a route that invokes given callback with parameters that correspond to the parts of the path remainder when current location matches with given path (#/… or /…); the final parameter is set to all remaining parts joined with slashes (glob); if the callback has no parameters, an exact match is required; returns a signal connection that can be used to unregister.

text.content: Note: This class is used internally by Application.

items.name: ActivityResourcePath
items.doc: Represents a resource path (URL/hash segment) that is handled by one or more activities.

items.name: Match
items.doc: Information for a resource path match.

items.name: isHash
items.doc: True if location matched by hash (part after #/…).

items.name: location
items.doc: The path name or hash prefix that was matched.

items.name: remainder
items.doc: The remainder of the location after the matching prefix, without leading slash (if any).

items.name: new ActivityResourcePath
items.doc: Create a new resource path from given parts (string, ResourceActivity instance, or another resource path).

items.name: concat
items.doc: Append a part to the end of this path and return new path.

items.name: match
items.doc: Check if given URL or path (e.g. http://… or /… or #/…) matches this path (or a sub path); returns matching prefix and remainder if matched successfully, undefined otherwise.

items.name: toString
items.doc: Returns the URL that can be used e.g. in href attributes; does not contain final slash so can be concatenated.

text.title: Usage
text.content:
This class enables building resource paths from several parts, and is used internally to match paths against each other.

class MyCountersActivity extends UI.SingletonViewActivity {
    constructor() {
        super("Counters", "#/counters");
    }
    // ...
}

class MyCounterActivity extends UI.ViewActivity {
    constructor(id: string, name: string) {
        super(name);

        // concatenate resource path
        this.resourcePath = new ActivityResourcePath(
            MyCountersActivity.getInstance(), id);
    }
    // ...
}

items.name: ActivitySignal
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when a change in the activity stack occurs.

items.name: ActivityStack
items.doc: Represents a stack of activated activities (like browser history).

items.name: TRACE_LOG
items.doc: Set to true to enable trace logging (on console.log) for activity operations.

items.name: contains
items.doc: Returns true if the stack contains given activity.

items.name: getHistoryState
items.doc: Get an ID that represents the current state, for use with .restoreHistoryStateAsync.

items.name: getParent
items.code: getParent<T>(ActivityClass: typeof Activity & { new (...args): T; }, before?: Activity): T | undefined;
items.doc: Get the activity closest to the foreground of the given type, if any (excluding foreground activity itself, and before given activity in second parameter, if any).

items.name: getViewComponent
items.doc: Get Component instance for given named outlet, from the view activity closest to the foreground that has given outlet mapped using .mapView(...) or the mapToActivity(...) decorator on a view Component class.

items.name: length
items.doc: The number of activities on the stack (observable).

items.name: popAsync
items.code:
popAsync(): PromiseLike<ActivityTransition>;
popAsync(activity: Activity): PromiseLike<ActivityTransition | null>;
items.doc:
[1]. Remove the current foreground activity (go back) asynchronously, returns Promise that resolves to the completed transition.

[2]. Remove the current foreground activity (go back) asynchronously if and only if it is the given activity, returns Promise that resolves to the completed transition, if any.

items.name: pushAsync
items.doc: Add an activity to the foreground asynchronously, does nothing if given activity was already in the foreground; returns Promise that resolves to the completed transition.

items.name: replaceAsync
items.doc: Replace the current activity asynchronously (throws error if none), or remove current activity if given activity was already directly below current activity in the activity stack; returns Promise that resolves to the completed transition.

items.name: restoreHistoryStateAsync
items.doc: Reload state using given history ID, if possible (i.e. not yet deactivated relevant activities in the meantime); returns a promise that resolves when the state has been reached.

items.name: title
items.doc: The title of the topmost activity that has a title defined (observable).

items.name: top
items.doc: The current foreground activity (top of stack, if any; observable).

items.name: upAsync
items.code: upAsync(activityOrClass: Activity | typeof Activity): PromiseLike<Activity | null>;
items.doc: Remove foreground activities until given activity or activity of given type is in the foreground; returns Promise that resolves to activity, or null if there was no matching activity on the stack.

items.name: Transition
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when a transition occurs (after Activating/Resuming/Suspending but before Activated/Resumed).

text.title: See Also
text.content: The most frequently used activity stack is part of the Application instance, referenced by its activities property.

items.name: ActivityTransition
items.doc: Represents a transition from one foreground activity to another.

items.name: Operation
items.doc: Operation type that triggered a transition.

items.name: Pop
items.doc: Pop operation

items.name: Push
items.doc: Push operation

items.name: Replace
items.doc: Replace operation

items.name: activityStack
items.doc: The activity stack that is transitioning.

items.name: from
items.doc: The activity that is currently in the foreground, if any.

items.name: id
items.doc: Unique ID for this transition.

items.name: operation
items.doc: The stack operation being performed: push, replace, or pop.

items.name: previous
items.doc: The previous transition that is part of the same operation (pop/push/pop/up).

items.name: to
items.doc: The new foreground activity, if any.

items.name: Application
items.doc: Encapsulates the application as a singleton object.

items.name: current
items.doc: The current (and only) Application instance, when created.

items.name: disableBrowserHistory
items.doc: Disable synchronization of activity stack with browser history.

items.name: mapActivity
items.code:
static mapActivity(activity: ResourceActivity): void;
static mapActivity(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[], activity?: Activity | typeof Activity): void;
items.doc:
[1]. Map resource activity on its path (using .resourcePath).

[2]. Map given path (#/… or /…) to given activity (i.e. instance or instance of class through static getInstance method).

items.name: mapResource
items.code: static mapResource(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[], callback: (...params: string[]) => Activity | Activity[] | PromiseLike<Activity | Activity[]> | undefined): Async.SignalConnection;
items.doc: Map given path (#/… or /…) to given callback; if callback has no parameters, an exact path match is required; otherwise callback is called with path remainder split on / characters plus glob (last parameter); callback should return an activity or array of activities (or a promise that resolves to either), returned ResourceActivity instances without a resource path will get the requested path set as their resource path automatically.

items.name: ready
items.doc: Promise that resolves to the application instance after it has been created.

items.name: new Application
items.doc: Create the application instance (either from a derived class or from the Application class itself); can be called only once.

items.name: activities
items.doc: Activity stack instance.

items.name: dropActivity
items.doc: Go back in activity history; either to previous activity or to activity of given class; returns promise that resolves to the new foreground activity, or null if activity was not found; the NoActivity signal is emitted if all activities have been dropped and there is no current activity anymore.

items.name: getTopActivity
items.doc: Returns the activity that is currently in the foreground (observable).

items.name: getViewComponent
items.doc: Get Component instance for given named outlet, from the view activity closest to the foreground that has given outlet mapped using .mapView(...) or the mapToActivity(...) decorator on a view Component class; can be used as an observable getter to obtain an observable value that changes when activities are started or suspended.

items.name: isActive
items.doc:
[1]. Returns true if the given path matches or is a prefix of the currently active path (e.g. #/items is considered active if the current path is #/items/123 or #/items).

[2]. Returns true if the current activity or one of its parent activities is an instance of the given activity class.

[3]. Returns true if the given activity matches the current activity or one of its parent activities.

items.name: mapActivity
items.code:
mapActivity(activity: ResourceActivity): void;
mapActivity(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[], activity?: Activity | typeof Activity): void;
items.doc:
[1]. Map resource activity on its path (using .resourcePath); returns this; also available as a static method.

[2]. Map given path (#/… or /…) to given activity (i.e. instance or instance of class through static getInstance method); returns this; also available as a static method.

items.name: mapResource
items.code: mapResource(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[], callback: (...params: string[]) => Activity | Activity[] | PromiseLike<Activity | Activity[]>): this;
items.doc: Map given path (#/… or /…) to given callback; if callback has no parameters, an exact path match is required; otherwise callback is called with path remainder split on / characters except last parameter (glob); callback should return an activity or array of activities (or a promise that resolves to either), returned ResourceActivity instances without a resource path will get the requested path set as their resource path automatically; returns this; also available as a static method.

items.name: startActivity
items.code: startActivity(activityOrPath: Activity | typeof Activity | ActivityResourcePath | string, replace?: boolean, setHrefIfNotFound?: boolean): PromiseLike<ActivityTransition[]>;
items.doc: Start given activity as foreground activity (push/replace, same as calling .activities.push/replace(…) directly), or start activity using given resource path or string (#/… or /…, or relative path as #./…, #…/…, ./… or …/…); if setHrefIfNotFound is not false, then window.location.href is set to the new location if no matching activity is found (automatic for external URLs), otherwise invokes onPageNotFound handler; note that activities transition asynchronously and any updates may not be reflected until several milliseconds after calling this method.

items.name: title
items.doc: The application name to be displayed in the title bar (observed), overridden by the title of the current activity/ies, if any.

items.name: NoActivity
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when all activities have been dropped and none have been started.

items.name: PageNotFound
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when no activity is found for a location.

text.title: Example
text.content:
// Redirect to #/ and log a warning message
Application.current.PageNotFound.connect(path => {
    console.log("Page not found: " + path);
    Application.startActivity("#/");
})

text.title: Usage
text.content:
This class can either be used directly, or can be used as a base class.

To create a basic Application instance and start a root activity, use new Application directly:

class MyRootActivity extends UI.RootViewActivity {
    // ...
}

// start the application
var app = new UI.Application();
app.startActivity(MyRootActivity);

To customize the Application class, simply derive from it:

class MyApplication extends UI.Application {
    constructor() {
        super("My Application");
        this.startActivity(MyRootActivity);
    }

    // now you can use public properties on the instance
    @Async.observable
    public myModel = {
        categories: []  // ...
    };
}

// start the application
new MyApplication();

items.name: ApplicationSignal
items.doc: A signal that is emitted by Application.

items.name: Http
items.doc: Namespace that encapsulates .fetch and related functionality.

items.name: FetchHeaders
items.doc: Interface definition for the simple read-only methods of a native Headers instance.

items.name: get
items.doc: Returns the first value of a single header by name.

items.name: getAll
items.doc: Returns all values of a single header by name (e.g. Accept-Encoding).

items.name: has
items.doc: Returns true if this instance contains the given header.

items.name: keys
items.code: keys(): { next(): { done?: boolean; value?: string; }; };
items.doc: Returns an iterator that lists all headers by name (polyfill only supports manual iteration with the next method for compatibility).

items.name: FetchOptions
items.doc: Interface definition for supported fetch options.

items.name: body
items.doc: Request body (string, or possibly a Blob if using the native fetch implementation).

items.name: headers
items.doc: Request headers (object literal or native Headers instance).

items.name: method
items.doc: The HTTP method (GET, PUT, POST, DELETE, etc).

items.name: url
items.doc: The URL to send a request to.

items.name: FetchResponse
items.doc: Interface definition for Response properties available in the native Fetch implementation as well as the polyfill implementation.

items.name: blob
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body read into a Blob, if supported.

items.name: headers
items.doc: Headers returned to the client.

items.name: json
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body, parsed as JSON.

items.name: ok
items.doc: True if the response was successful (status 200-299).

items.name: status
items.doc: Status code of the response.

items.name: statusText
items.doc: Status message

items.name: text
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body.

items.name: GlobalConfig
items.doc: Configuration options (for exported config variable).

items.name: FETCH_INCLUDE_CREDENTIALS
items.doc: Automatically set fetch credentials mode to “include” (defaults to true).

items.name: FORCE_XHR_FETCH
items.doc: Force fetch to use XMLHttpRequest instead of native fetch implementation (defaults to false).

items.name: Headers
items.doc: Definition of a collection of HTTP headers as an object.

items.name: [string]
items.doc: No description

items.name: MockResponse
items.doc: Implements the FetchResponse interface, can be used to mock responses or initialize a response from an XMLHttpRequest.

items.name: withJSONContent
items.doc: Create a response with given data encoded as JSON, the application/json content type, and status 200.

items.name: new MockResponse
items.code: constructor(init?: { status?: number; statusText?: string; responseText?: string; response?: Blob; }, headers?: FetchHeaders);
items.doc: Create a response with given properties (an XMLHttpRequest object can be passed in directly, along with a native fetch Headers instance or a MockResponseHeaders instance); the response itself is taken from .responseText if it is not undefined, or from .response if it is a Blob.

items.name: blob
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body read into a Blob, if supported.

items.name: headers
items.doc: Headers returned to the client.

items.name: json
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body, parsed as JSON.

items.name: ok
items.doc: True if the response was successful (status 200-299).

items.name: status
items.doc: Status code of the response.

items.name: statusText
items.doc: Status message

items.name: text
items.doc: Returns a promise for the response body.

items.name: MockResponseHeaders
items.doc: Implements the FetchResponse interface, can be used to mock response headers or initialize response headers from an XMLHttpRequest.

items.name: new MockResponseHeaders
items.doc: Initialize the list of headers using given HTTP header text (i.e. one or more lines with header name, colon, and header value; strips all whitespace around names and values).

items.name: get
items.doc: No description

items.name: getAll
items.doc: No description

items.name: has
items.doc: No description

items.name: keys
items.code: keys(): { next: () => { done?: boolean | undefined; value?: string | undefined; }; };
items.doc: No description

items.name: Requesting
items.doc: Signal that is emitted before sending a request; can be used to intercept requests, modify request options, and provide an alternate response; if one of the connected handlers returns a (promise for) an alternate response, i.e. an object that implements FetchResponse, then the request will not be sent, and the (first) resulting alternate response is used instead; if one of the connected handlers throws an exception, the original promise for the request is rejected; otherwise the request is sent as per normal.

items.name: Responded
items.doc: Signal that is emitted after obtaining a remote response (from an actual request, not an alternate response provided by a connected handler of .Requesting).

items.name: config
items.doc: Configuration options

items.name: deleteAsync
items.code: function deleteAsync(url: string, data?: any, headers?: Headers): PromiseLike<FetchResponse>;
items.doc: Perform a DELETE request with given object (sent as JSON) and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the parsed JSON response (or undefined if response was empty), or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

items.name: fetch
items.code:
function fetch(inputUrl: string, init?: FetchOptions): PromiseLike<FetchResponse>;
function fetch(inputRequest: any): PromiseLike<FetchResponse>;
items.doc:
[1]. Perform a request to fetch a resource at given URL; provides a partial polyfill for the Fetch standard using XMLHttpRequest, but uses native fetch() internally if available.

[2]. Perform a request to fetch a resource; provides a partial polyfill for the Fetch standard using XMLHttpRequest, but uses native fetch internally if available.

items.name: getAsync
items.code: function getAsync(url: string, params?: any, headers?: Headers | FetchHeaders): PromiseLike<any>;
items.doc: Perform a GET request with given parameters and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the parsed JSON response (or undefined if response was empty), or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

items.name: getBlobAsync
items.code: function getBlobAsync(url: string, params?: any, headers?: Headers | FetchHeaders): PromiseLike<Blob>;
items.doc: Perform a GET request with given parameters and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to a blob, or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range; requires a browser that supports Blob constructors.

items.name: getHtmlContentAsync
items.code: function getHtmlContentAsync(url: string, params?: any, headers?: Headers | FetchHeaders): PromiseLike<DocumentFragment>;
items.doc: Perform a GET request with given parameters and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the parsed HTML result body as a document fragment (ignores everything before and after body tag, if any; inserts everything if no body tag is found, i.e. partial HTML), or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

items.name: getTextAsync
items.code: function getTextAsync(url: string, params?: any, headers?: Headers | FetchHeaders): PromiseLike<string>;
items.doc: Perform a GET request with given parameters and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the response text, or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

items.name: postAsync
items.code: function postAsync(url: string, data?: any, headers?: Headers): PromiseLike<FetchResponse>;
items.doc: Perform a POST request with given object (sent as JSON) and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the parsed JSON response (or undefined if response was empty), or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

items.name: putAsync
items.code: function putAsync(url: string, data?: any, headers?: Headers): PromiseLike<FetchResponse>;
items.doc: Perform a PUT request with given object (sent as JSON) and headers, if any; returns a promise that resolves to the parsed JSON response (or undefined if response was empty), or gets rejected if the request fails or response status is not in 2xx range.

text.content:
This mini-toolkit is provided to simplify development of single-page applications that rely on asynchronous HTTP communication with their Web server. This toolkit library is not intended to be a full framework for all types of client-server communication.

However, since most applications won’t need much more than simple “Ajax”-style REST requests to transfer HTML or JSON data anyway—and there are no simple ways to achieve this in a cross-browser solution using Promises, the Http toolkit at least provides the basics.

text.title: Exported members
text.content:
This namespace module exports the following classes and methods:

  • .fetch function — mimics the window.fetch function in modern browsers. Internally uses either XMLHttpRequest or the native fetch implementation (when available) to process requests and responses, and always returns a Promise for a response object.
  • .getTextAsync and .getBlobAsync — to perform a GET request and return a Promise for the text or blob response data.
  • .getHtmlContentAsync — to perform a GET request and return a Promise for a document fragment that contains everything in the HTML response’s <body>.
  • .getAsync, .postAsync, .putAsync, and .deleteAsync — wrapper functions that send JSON data and return a promise for a parsed JSON response.
  • Http.MockResponse and Http.MockResponseHeaders — can be used to generate mock responses, and used internally to transform XMLHttpRequest data.
  • Http.Requesting and Http.Responded signals — for intercepting requests and responses.
  • Http.options object — contains options for default behavior of the fetch function.

Refer to the samples for common usage patterns.

items.name: ResourceActivity
items.doc: Represents an activity pertaining to a resource (URL path).

items.name: new ResourceActivity
items.doc: Create an activity with given resource path.

items.name: resourcePath
items.doc: The path (URL/hash segment) that is associated with this activity.

items.name: RootViewActivity
items.doc: Represents a singleton view activity that is both a root activity (i.e. may exist only once on the activity stack, starting/replacing the activity again transitions the stack up to the existing activity instead), and a hub activity (i.e. starting any activity that specifies this activity as its parent activity, transitions the stack up to the hub activity first, suspending all other activities that used to be in the foreground); abstract class, needs to be overridden.

items.name: new RootViewActivity
items.code: constructor(title?: string, path?: ActivityResourcePath | string, view?: Component | Page);
items.doc: No description

items.name: SingletonViewActivity
items.doc: Represents an activity that corresponds to a component or page on screen, created only once and re-used if required (overrides .getInstance static method); abstract class, needs to be overridden.

items.name: getInstance
items.doc: Get the instance of this activity class, constructs the instance without parameters once and returns this instance every time.

items.name: new SingletonViewActivity
items.code: constructor(title?: string, path?: ActivityResourcePath | string, view?: Component | Page, parent?: Activity | typeof Activity);
items.doc: Create a new activity; can be used only once.

items.name: ViewActivity
items.doc: Represents an activity that corresponds to a (component or Page on) screen.

items.name: new ViewActivity
items.code: constructor(title?: string, path?: ActivityResourcePath | string, view?: Component | Page, parent?: Activity | typeof Activity);
items.doc: Create a view activity with optional title and view instance, parent reference, and resource path; to add a view component/page dynamically, use the mapToActivity(...) decorator on a view Component or Page class, or call the .mapView(...) method on this activity.

items.name: getViewByName
items.doc: Get an instance of the view component/page for given named outlet on this activity, or main view if none given, by calling the mapped view getter that has been registered through the .mapView(...) method (within unobserved function wrapper to avoid observable side effects).

items.name: mapView
items.code: mapView(f: (fg: ViewActivity) => (Component | Page), outlet?: string): void;
items.doc: Register given function to return the view instance for given outlet name, or for the main view if none given; existing getter for the same outlet is replaced, if any; getter must always return a component/page instance, which may be the same instance every time; the function may accept a single parameter, which is the foreground activity (i.e. this activity, or another ViewActivity instance that refers to this activity as a parent activity).

items.name: view
items.doc: The main view component/page that is currently displayed, if any; this is a readonly field, to link a view to an activity use the mapToActivity(...) decorator on a view Component or Page class, or call the .mapView(...) method on a view activity.

items.name: Displayed
items.doc: Signal that is emitted after this activity is displayed in the foreground (i.e. NOT if displayed as parent view).

items.name: Displaying
items.doc: Signal that is emitted before this activity’s view is displayed in the foreground (i.e. NOT if displayed as parent view).

items.name: ViewActivitySignal
items.doc: Signal that is emitted when a change in the activity stack occurs.

items.name: ViewActivityTransition
items.doc: Represents a transition from one (view) activity to a view activity that is to be displayed, encapsulates activity transition.

items.name: firstDisplay
items.doc: True if displaying this view for the first time (i.e. the activity has just been added, and not resumed or added again).

items.name: forward
items.doc: True if adding this view to the browser history (i.e. not resuming from history).

items.name: hops
items.doc: Number of transitions in the current chain (for checking if e.g. a dropActivity(…) call crossed multiple activities to get to this view).

items.name: transition
items.doc: The activity transition itself.

items.name: view
items.doc: The main view, if any, displayed as a result of this transition.

items.name: PathInitializerPart
items.doc: No description

items.name: findActivity
items.code: function findActivity<T>(ActivityClass: typeof Activity & { new (...args): T; }): T | undefined;
items.doc: Get the activity closest to the foreground of given type, if any.

items.name: startActivity
items.code: function startActivity(activityOrPath: Activity | typeof Activity | ActivityResourcePath | string, replace?: boolean, setHrefIfNotFound?: boolean): PromiseLike<ActivityTransition[]>;
items.doc: Alias for Application#startActivity on the current Application instance; if there is no current instance, this function waits for the instance to be created first.

items.name: mapPageToActivity
items.code: function mapPageToActivity<ActivityT extends ViewActivity, ComponentT extends Component>(activityClass: { new (...args: any[]): ActivityT; }, outlet?: string, dereferenceTimeout?: number): (target: { new (activity: ActivityT): ComponentT; }) => void;
items.doc: Class decorator, maps the decorated view Page class (with a constructor that has a single matching activity argument) to a ViewActivity class as given named outlet, or as the main view if none specified; view instances are re-used when possible, but are dereferenced within given timeout when no longer in use (in ms, defaults to 2s, set to 0 to disable) [decorator].

items.name: mapToActivity
items.code: function mapToActivity<ActivityT extends ViewActivity, ComponentT extends Component>(activityClass: { new (...args: any[]): ActivityT; }, outlet?: string, dereferenceTimeout?: number): (target: { new (activity: ActivityT): ComponentT; }) => void;
items.doc: Class decorator, maps the decorated view Component class (with a constructor that has a single matching activity argument) to a ViewActivity class as given named outlet, or as the main view if none specified; view instances are re-used when possible, but are dereferenced within given timeout when no longer in use (in ms, defaults to 2s, set to 0 to disable) [decorator].

items.name: mapToPath
items.code: function mapToPath(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[]): (target: typeof Activity) => void;
items.doc: Class decorator, maps the decorated Activity class to given path (using Application.mapActivity method) [decorator].

items.name: mapToResource
items.code: function mapToResource(path: PathInitializerPart | PathInitializerPart[]): (target: new (glob: string) => Activity) => void;
items.doc: Class decorator, maps the decorated Activity class to simple sub resources on given path (using Application.mapResource method, use that method directly for more options), but not the path itself; the activity class must have a constructor that takes a single string parameter, i.e. the resource path glob [decorator].
